isis.stitle: HYDRO-MAX™ BRAKE BOOSTER AND MASTER CYLINDER - OPERATION - MASTER CYLINDER ASSEMBLY

svcproc.title: MASTER CYLINDER ASSEMBLY
svcproc.para: Refer to Figure 2 for all items in parentheses.

The master cylinder assembly includes a brake fluid reservoir (Item 8) and a master cylinder body (Item 2) that contains both a primary and a secondary piston, forming separate primary and secondary fluid chambers respectively. The reservoir and bore are connected by two compensation valves, primary and secondary.

When the brake pedal is pushed, the Hydro-Max™ booster (Item 1) pushes on the primary piston. This causes the primary piston to move, which closes the primary compensation valve, sealing off the primary bore chamber from the reservoir and pushes brake fluid out to the brakes. As primary pressure builds, with increased force on the brake pedal, this pressure begins to move the secondary piston. Then the secondary compensation valve closes, sealing off the secondary bore chamber and the secondary piston pushes brake fluid out to the brakes.

When the force on the brake pedal is released, springs return the primary and secondary pistons to their at-rest positions, which opens the compensation valves. The open compensation valves allow the brake fluid in the master cylinder body (Item 2) to expand or contract with changes in temperature, without building pressure in the cylinder bore (which could cause brake drag) or causing a vacuum to occur in the master cylinder bore (which could suck air into the brake fluid lines).

The primary and secondary systems are isolated from each other by an arrangement of seals. The pressure differential switch (Item 9) is exposed to the pressure in each system. The pressure differential switch reacts to significant differences in pressure between the primary and secondary systems. For example, if there is a significant leak in one system, when the brake pedal is applied, pressure will not build in this system but pressure will build in the other system. The pressure differential switch will respond to this difference and close an electrical circuit that turns on the warning light in the vehicle instrument panel.
